Last night, the YPS Board of Education voted for our Pre-K through 3rd grade Continuous Learning students to return to the traditional classroom setting on September 16th and 4th grade through 12th grade Continuous Learning students to return on September 21st.

In the “Supe Talk” video distributed August 7th, Dr. Simeroth referenced the district would consider a return to the traditional classroom setting when Canadian County maintained fewer than ten positive COVID-19 cases per 100,000 people for two consecutive weeks. Canadian County was below this threshold for the weeks of August 14th and August 21st, therefore the item was placed on the September board agenda.

After much consideration and lengthy discussion, the YPS Board of Education voted to return to the traditional classroom setting sooner than originally projected. This decision reflects the district’s focus on meeting both the educational and social-emotional needs of our students.

Current options for YPS families include:

- Traditional/Continuous Learning Plan - Parents/Guardians of students currently enrolled in Yukon Virtual School who are interested in the traditional classroom setting may transition to Traditional/Continuous Learning Plan. We ask that you do so as soon as possible by contacting virtual@yukonps.com.

- Yukon Virtual School - Due to the number of students transitioning from Yukon Virtual School (YVS) to the traditional school setting, there are a limited number of YVS seats available. If you are interested in continuing school remotely, please email virtual@yukonps.com.

- YPS Re-Enrollment - Parents/Guardians of students currently enrolled in out-of-district educational options are always welcome to return to Yukon Public Schools. Please contact our YPS Enrollment Center at 405-265-1300 or email enrollment.center@yukonps.com.

Parents/Guardians of students in the Traditional/Continuous Learning Plan are encouraged to be prepared throughout the school year for sudden school closures and possible transitions to at-home learning.

Yukon vs. Mustang game rescheduled to Saturday, September 5 at 6:00 pm at Yukon High School Stadium

Given that our Yukon Miller football season opener was scheduled for this Friday at 7:00 pm against the Mustang Broncos, their quarantine will force the game to be rescheduled to Saturday, September 5 at 6:00 pm at Yukon High School stadium.

“Yukon Miller staff has done an amazing job at enforcing procedures and protocols that keep our players and program safe,” said Yukon Head Coach Jeremy Reed. “Although we are disappointed we won’t be able to play on Friday, we are excited to play on Saturday and glad all of the Mustang players are able to participate.”

No refunds will be available and all tickets sold will be honored as before. For ticket information or to purchase live streaming, please visit athletics.yukonps.com/home/tickets

YPSFE is a 501(c)(3) fully funded through grants and donations. If you are interested in helping educators within Yukon Public Schools, the Foundation for Excellence is always accepting new members and donations; you can find more information at ypsfe.org.

YPS Families,

Thank you for your patience through this process. There are still so many unknowns but we are receiving your questions and concerns and want to let you know we hear you. YPS leadership is working hard to provide answers regarding distance learning, picking up property, graduation, yearbooks, summer camp, driver’s education and more. The district wants to reassure you that we will communicate answers to you as soon as we have them. The updated information and answers we have as of Thursday, March 26, 2020 include the following:

Regarding meals, breakfasts and lunches are available for pick-up only in the drop-off lanes at Central, Myers, Independence, Lakeview, Ranchwood, Shedeck and Surrey Hills. Pick-up is between 11:15AM - 12:30PM each weekday for both breakfast and lunch.

Regarding checked-out books, boxes will be set up at each breakfast/lunch nutrition location for families to return checked-out library books and textbooks on weekdays between 11:15AM and 12:30PM at the above-mentioned school sites.

Regarding distance learning, on Wednesday, March 25th, the OK State Board of Education approved a recommendation by Superintendent Hofmeister to finish this school year with a form of "Distance Learning." Now that this recommendation has been approved, the OSDE is slated to release "Distance Learning Frameworks" designed to provide guidance to districts. Superintendent Hofmeister has made it very clear the OSDE acknowledges this form of education will look very different from grade level to grade level, from subject to subject and from district to district. We also acknowledge the goal is to reach every student to ensure equity and this may take different forms. Based on the most recent OSDE Conference Calls, "Distance Learning" is not intended to provide any new learning and will be used to focus on standards already taught from August to March 15th as well as the skills listed on the OSDE Family Guides for grade PK-6.

Regarding district grading, the goal during this unprecedented time is to hold our students harmless for the abrupt end of instruction. We know the last weeks of school are an essential time when it comes to demonstrating mastery of skills. Unfortunately, we do not have these weeks and we must rely on the evidence that has already been collected for each standard. Teachers and staff are taking into account the best interest of each student and grades will reflect what students have learned based on the essential standards for the third quarter.

As further solutions become clear, we will continue to communicate via our website at www.yukonps.com, our social media platforms and email communications with YPS guardians. “All of our YPS sites are working extremely hard to make this as positive of an experience as possible for everyone and to make it a beneficial learning opportunity for both students and staff. We will all grow through this together and come out stronger on the other side” assured YPS Superintendent, Dr. Simeroth.

Video Message from Dr. Simeroth: https://youtu.be/8yXmTMGNT5MVid

Today, state officials announced they will recommend to the state Board of Education that Oklahoma students not return to the classroom for the remainder of the current school year, as our state continues to fight the spread of COVID-19. They will instead recommend a continuous learning plan that will allow students to complete the school year at home. It is important to note that this decision is not final until the state Board of Education meets on Wednesday and votes to approve the recommendation.

We are sharing this information with you in advance, however, so that you can begin to prepare accordingly for your family. We understand this recommendation is in the best interest of everyone’s health, which is our greatest priority as a district. If approved, this also means that all extracurricular activities and special events will be canceled as well. Making these difficult decisions, we believe, is simply the right thing to do for our students, our staff and our community.

We do have good news: Yukon Public Schools is developing a plan to ensure your child will continue to have opportunities to learn and to grow academically, especially with parental support. Because we are unable to safely gather together, these lessons and activities will primarily be delivered and communicated via distance learning methods. As you can imagine, this is a significant transition for our students and our teachers. Yukon Public Schools will spend the next two weeks planning for this effort and will share details with your family as soon as they are available. Teachers and support staff members will hear from their principals soon as they gather input regarding the next phase of the school closure.

For students, it likely will be sad and disappointing to learn that school as they know it will not resume this year. Please give them a safe place to express their feelings and to vent about the changes in their life. For our seniors and their parents, we know it is an especially difficult time. We will do everything possible to ensure their efforts are recognized and celebrated in special and unique ways. This is an unfair situation, but please reassure them that it does not diminish their achievements. In fact, it will become one more example of how they demonstrated their strength as a Yukon Miller.

We have posted numerous resources on our website, including information about free breakfasts and lunches for students under the age of 18, which will continue, as well as answers to frequently asked questions regarding the school closure. You can find these details and more by visiting www.yukonps.com. The site also includes recommendations from the CDC about protecting your health and the health of your loved ones. We ask you to please following their advice by: (1) washing your hands regularly; (2) staying at home, if you can; and (3) practicing social distancing of at least six feet from others.

This is an unprecedented situation, and it has required an unprecedented response. We can still take care of Yukon’s students, though. This is a community that sticks together in challenging times, and we know this experience will be no different. As soon as we identify our next steps, we will share them with you.

Please stay safe. As always, we appreciate your support of Yukon Public Schools.

State Superintendent of Public Instruction Joy Hofmeister has called an emergency meeting of the State Board of Education for 4 p.m. today to authorize the closure of all Oklahoma schools beginning March 17 and lasting until April 6. Hofmeister said the Oklahoma State Department of Education (OSDE) will closely monitor the COVID-19 situation with state health experts to determine if it will be necessary to extend the closure.

“Nothing is more important than the safety and well-being of Oklahomans,” Hofmeister said. “It is critical that we do everything in our power to protect the health of our kids, their families, educators and all vulnerable populations. That need outweighs everything else. The OSDE has been working around the clock, and will continue to do so, to ease the burden of schools during this challenging time.”

“This decision is not made lightly, but it is the right thing to do based on current guidance from the CDC,” said Governor Kevin Stitt. “This closure will allow us time to further understand how COVID-19 is affecting Oklahoma and give students and staff a period of time to be protected from further community spread of the virus. We know closing schools has a significant impact on families, and we are committed to doing what we can to lessen that impact as we work to prioritize the health and safety of all Oklahomans.”

Yukon Public Schools is monitoring this situation and will provide updated information on the impact to our families, students, and employees after the board meeting concludes and we receive updated information from the State.

2020 MILL Week Recipient: Tessa Bynum

MILL stands for Millers Improving Local Lives and this year, we have the opportunity to support Tessa Bynum and her family. A third grader at Parkland Elementary, Tessa is a ray of sunshine. Her father, Darin Bynum, is a math teacher at Yukon Middle School. Tessa was diagnosed in 2010 with Congenital CMV, a virus that caused severe brain damage affecting the function of her body. Tessa has limited mobility and uses a wheelchair but that doesn’t slow her down from being a light in every room she enters.

This family is extraordinary because of the passion they have for those around them. Rather than asking for support to purchase equipment to meet the family’s physical needs, the family asks that you join on their journey to create something bigger than themselves.

Their dream has always been to create a non-profit known as “Every Creation Matters”—a fully accessible and inclusive pottery studio that allows all types of families to participate and make memories. The goal is for all people to understand “not just every art creation matters, but each one of God’s creations matters.”

Check out www.millweek2020.wordpress.com to see how you can help!

Yukon Pom brought home the 6A state championship two years in a row but few people know the entirety of what these athletes put into their practice. “Unlike most sports, competition is not our number one priority,” said Mrs. Reape, YHS Pom Sponsor. “We are a spirit squad, so we are responsible for supporting other teams first before we focus on competition.”

The squad practices around ten hours a week, on game days, over winter break, over fall break and they do not have an off-season. “During any given half-count of a performance, every part of their bodies have to be in an exact position, completely synchronized, taking teamwork to a new level,” said Reape. “When we perform our championship-winning routine, the untrained eye might think it looks cool but not understand the technicality and skill going into every move.”

The girls know what it takes to win so they work hard and set a high bar for new members. On top of the technical execution, their facial expressions and emotions are judged as well. “It takes performing with passion to win,” said one YHS dancer. “We want people to know that we do more than cheer at games, most of us are in this for the competition and we work very hard to make sure we win.”

YHS Pom is leaving for Nationals in Florida on January 29. Last year, they received second place by only one point, so they are laser-focused on bringing home the National Championship in 2020.

Within the agreement, SWOSU will allow YPS juniors and seniors to enroll in up to 18 hours of concurrent enrollment tuition-free, providing eligible high school students with an opportunity to earn college credit.

YPS employees will receive tuition at a discounted rate for education-related undergraduate and graduate courses from SWOSU and YPS will offer classroom space for SWOSU undergraduate and graduate courses, providing easier access for local residents to pursue higher education as well.

“Collaborative partnerships like this one are key to a school community’s success” said State Superintendent of Public Instruction Joy Hofmeister. “Not only can students participate in higher education learning while still in high school, educators are able to gain valuable knowledge that they can pass along to their students. I’m proud of Yukon for seeking out and supporting an opportunity to give a boost to their students and staff.”

Encouraging self-expression is a goal for most middle-school students and Ms. Josey’s Special Education LIFE (Learning in a Functional Environment) program is no different. Recently, they focused on thumbs up and thumbs down communication. "With daily practice, the semblance of fingers folding into the palm was becoming visible for one student" said Ms. Josey. “On the third week of practice, while enjoying a cookie, he wrapped four-fingers inside his palm and his thumb flexed into the air.”

Another student requires assistive technology for the majority of her communication needs. After much effort, she can now form full sentences with her technology. “Our wins may not be typical for middle school demographics” said Ms. Josey, “but we are thrilled to share our triumphs!”

Mrs. Tews and Ms. Donaldson’s English students held mock trials pleading the guilt or innocence of the main character of “Lamb to the Slaughter” by Roald Dahl. After reading the short story, students were assigned positions of either prosecutor or defense attorney for Mary Maloney, the fictional main character accused of murder.

The students braided their character analysis, knowledge of our United States justice system and enthusiasm for competition to produce very impressive arguments throughout the trials. Volunteer judges and a jury of fellow students made their determination based on the persuasiveness of each argument. What a great learning experience!

If you would have walked into Ms. Burris’s first grade classroom, you may have transported into a doctor’s office, pirate ship or airplane. Currently an Instructional Specialist at IES, Ms. Burris founded Operation Engagement, a nonprofit organization that provides classroom transformations that promote collaboration, creativity and critical thinking.

“When I started teaching, I had 6-year-olds that didn’t want to come to school,” said Burris. “I knew these children deserved to love learning so I had to ask myself what I could do to make education fun for them.” Burris started to research how to make her classroom engaging without sacrificing the skills or rigorous standards.

She began by transforming her classroom into a doctor’s office. She went to a dollar store and bought shower curtains to section off an “operating room” and purchased gloves and hats for the students. Throughout the week, they performed sentence surgery, subtraction surgery and measured the length of bones from a printed x-ray. Throughout the day, she would stop and shout “Code Red” and put a sight word or math problem on the board for them to solve. The students took turns being patients and doctors and the doctors would help their patients learn the skill so they could mark them as “healthy.”

“I got incredible feedback from the parents, students were crying if they had to miss a day of school,” said Burris. She packed up the doctor’s kit in a Rubbermaid Tub and started working on her next transformation. Over time, it grew into a sort of library system, where teachers could check out kits with no cost and word spread all around Oklahoma.

Since becoming an official nonprofit organization in August 2019, Operation Engagement has impacted 627 students from 2-year-olds up to 6th grade. To learn more, rent a kit or volunteer, please visit https://operationengagement.org

Anna Langert is the first YHS student to be named Academic All American by the National Speech & Debate Association.

Less than 1% of students nationwide qualify for this prestigious award based on GPA, ACT score and NSDA points earned at tournaments. “To qualify, you have to have 750 points. To put that into perspective, the most someone can earn in a one hour round is six points. I have competed in over 200 rounds since I was a freshman,” said Anna.

The senior is triple-qualified for NSDA Regionals in Original Oratory, Poetry and Humorous Duet. “In Speech and Debate, we’re not just performing to entertain” Anna continued, “we perform with a clearly defined message; we research, study, write content, and present a passionate and valid argument on a topic.” Anna’s original oratory discusses how society uses blame as an excuse to avoid finding real solutions, her poetry piece brings awareness to mental health and she and her partner’s duet 'Sealed for Freshness: A Tupperware Party Gone Awry' presents a message about feminism and shattering stereotypes of women.

“Speech and Debate provides skills to take with us throughout the rest of our life, not only how to present a persuasive argument but how to be open-minded, how to explore topics from different perspectives, and how to find depth and meaning within ordinary life scenarios.”

Anna credits Mr. Pipkin, YHS Speech and Debate Coach, for teaching her how to find true depth in communication. “He always makes sure we know the ‘why’ in our words and pushes us to see things from different perspectives. I am not the same person I was four years ago, he has really helped me grow so much.”

YHS Choral Director Darin Chapin received the Oklahoma Music Educators Association Exemplary Teacher Award based on his mastery of music education.

“Getting this award is flattering but it is a group effort. My brother and I run this together, the elementary and middle school teachers do a wonderful job of cultivating the talent, and our administration is so supportive, truly seeing the value of the arts.”

Chapin is currently in his eighteenth year of public school service in Oklahoma and his ninth year at Yukon High School where he conducts Colla Voce, the YHS Chamber Singers, and teaches AP Music Theory. Under the direction of brothers Darin and Derek Chapin, the YHS Choirs have won national choral festivals in San Antonio, Breckenridge, Dallas, Houston, Kansas City, and Chicago.

In his classes, Mr. Chapin's students study several subjects including poetry, history, science, mathematics, the human body, interpersonal communication and much more. “Choir is not only my vocation,” said Chapin. “It is my hobby; it’s how I spend my spare time. I don’t see myself ever doing anything else.”

YHS senior Mason O’Hara recently helped save a life via blood donation. O’Hara frequently donates blood and platelets with the hopes of helping someone in need. “I've donated blood every single time that I can,” O’Hara said. “I donated on my 16th birthday and then I donated that December, and then I donated that May, and I've done it every year since. I was just hoping that I would make a difference.”

O’Hara’s hopes of helping someone came true in October when he found out someone received three units of his blood in a life-saving transfusion.“I got a call, and they said that they traced my first donation to someone who had a transplant and a transfusion of blood,” O’Hara said. “His name was Ronald Black, and he received 59 units of blood. He had a liver transplant because he had liver cancer and he received my platelets.”

Hobbies, family, goals…these are the topics that fill the pages shared between Mr. Griswold’s 6th grade geography class and university students from all around the country.

Nearly six years ago, Mr. Griswold was looking for a way to help his students see beyond the classroom and into their future. He started reaching out to colleges requesting pen pal opportunities. Some didn’t respond, several sent swag instead but this year, five colleges agreed to participate: West Alabama, Holy Cross, University of Utah, University of Tennessee at Martin and Duke University.

On a regular basis, Mr. Griswold’s classes exchange letters with their assigned university pen pal, sharing encouragement, trivia and life updates. “Once these kids have someone who inspires them that they can look up to and admire, they start to develop more work ethic, better study habits and more of a future-focused mentality” said Griswold.

The pen pal program also weaves into their geography lessons, assigning value and excitement to previously unknown parts of the country. “My goal is that these students leave my classroom with a passion to never stop learning, wherever that may be.

Gena Barnhill, Lakeview Elementary teacher, was selected to receive a Presidential Award for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching. Administered by the National Science Foundation on behalf of the White House, this program awards outstanding teachers for their contributions to the teaching and learning of science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and/or computer science.

“I am simply humbled, honored, and excited. This award was reviewed by leaders in science education, administrators and my teaching peers, including past awardees” said Barnhill. “For these individuals to feel like I am making a difference in science and math education, makes me proud to bring innovative lessons to the students in my classroom.”

In January 2018, Barnhill began the extensive application process after being nominated by a colleague. She sent in a 30-minute video, eight pages of reflection, multiple letters of recommendation and a three-page resume. She became a state finalist in September 2018.

On October 15, 2019, the National Science Foundation announced Ms. Barnhill’s accolade. Each awardee received a citation signed by President Trump and an invitation to visit our nation’s capital. “The trip was a whirlwind” said Barnhill. “They provided wonderful professional development, a banquet dinner at the Kennedy Center, a ceremony at the Department of Interior and then we toured the White House” she smiled, “I can now mark that off my bucket list."

No Students / No Employees Report (Level III Closure)

Due to an ongoing investigation and additional threats made via social media to our schools, Yukon Public Schools will be closed tomorrow, Tuesday, September 17th. Yukon Public Schools is working closely with the Yukon Police Department, and in turn, the Yukon Police Department is working closely with Oklahoma State Bureau of Investigation and the Federal Bureau of Investigation to resolve these unsubstantiated threats. The safety of our students and employees is our primary concern. While we do not believe any of these threats to be credible, out of an abundance of caution we want to allow YPS and our law-enforcement partners to complete their investigations.

If you have any information regarding specific individuals involved in these social media threats or any other information regarding these threats please contact the Yukon Police Department at 405.354.2553.

Mr. Canon led his students on an exploration through Europe with the help of our district’s new virtual reality headsets. “Ooh”s and “Ahh”s filled the classroom as fingers pointed at blank ceiling tiles; the students were exploring new parts of the world while sitting in 7th hour geography class.

“The new headsets provide a much deeper look into the content” says Amanda Oneth, YPS Instructional Technology Coach. “Whether they’re exploring the Swiss Alps or crawling through foxholes, the students are receiving a more comprehensive view, which enriches their overall learning experience.”

Before using the headsets, each teacher has to be specifically trained on the technology and the Expeditions must be standards-based. “In this case, we used the headsets at the beginning of the unit as an anticipatory set” said Mr. Canon. “I wanted students to have an opportunity to really see Europe to wet their appetites for the unit to come.”

Constance Davis, Aspen Hein, and Carly Smarra represented Yukon Public Schools during an impressive performance at the Oklahoma State School Board Association Conference on August 23. The 2019 Oklahoma Junior High All State Chorus included 135 students from 42 school districts across the state.

To qualify for All State, the girls had to pass two meticulous rounds of auditions. Ironically, all three vocalists recall formerly auditioning for the Children’s All-State Choir but none of them qualified. “We kept working though, and now we’re here” said Constance. “This showed us that working hard can pay off and practice really does matter.”

The vocalists also noted that Ms. Massey, Choir Director at YMS, has been an amazing mentor, making sure they remain confident, comfortable and positive throughout the learning process.

Over the summer, YPS transportation department has implemented several upgrades to our school bus system. New Safety Vision’s mobile cameras have been strategically installed in the school buses to optimize vision into every single seat of the bus, consistently monitoring activity. The software also provides GPS tracking, live alerts, speed tracking and more. “Our primary goal is to keep our students safe” said Christy Clemons, Director of Transportation. “Being able to monitor on-board activity to this degree will promote accountability and enhance security all around.”

Also, most buses on route now include both heating and air conditioning, making the journey to and from school more comfortable for our students and drivers.

YPS Board of Education appointed Lance Haggard as the Executive Director of Elementary Education and Diana Lebsack as the Executive Director of Secondary Education. The new positions replace Dr. Sheli McAdoo, who accepted the position of Superintendent at Purcell Public Schools.

Haggard began his career in education teaching at Parkland Elementary in 1991. For the last twenty years, he has served as Head Principal at Parkland Elementary in Yukon.

“I am committed to working tirelessly to uphold our district's stellar reputation and expand educational opportunities across all classrooms” said Haggard. “While our school district continues to grow and prosper, I intend to continue the ‘small town’, communal feel that I have cherished over the years. We will continue to choose betterment over complacency as we educate future generations of Yukon Millers.”

Lebsack brings nearly twenty years of experience to her new role as Executive Director of Secondary Education. Most recently, she served as Head Principal at Yukon Middle School and formerly, Head Principal at Putnam City High School.

“My passion for secondary education started twenty years ago when I began teaching high school Biology and worked in the evenings as the principal of a credit recovery program for at risk students” said Lebsack. “I knew during those years I wanted to make a difference and help individual kids find their own path to success. I am beyond thrilled to continue working here in the Yukon community as part of a collaborative team of Yukon administrators.”

YUKON TEACHER AWARDED $5K INNOVATION GRANT

A Yukon teacher who just completed her first year in the classroom said this week that she is excited to begin her second year.
Shauna Walker, who teaches special education at Central Elementary School, recently learned that is she is one of 19 teachers across the state who will share $98,000 in innovative grants from Cox Communications.
Walker, who entered the teaching field last year, was awarded a $5,000 grant that will be used to fund a sensory exploration program.
Walker has seven students in her program. They range from kindergarten through third grade.
Most of the students are autistic.
“A lot of them have sensory issues, whether it be they need a lot of sensory input with touching or certain textures, or quite the opposite where they hate certain textures,” she said.
Walker said she plans to use the funds to purchase equipment, such as sensory bins that include water beads that have a “squishy sensation” or balls that have different textures.
One of the biggest items that Walker hopes to purchase are large floor couches called Pea Pods.
The couches look a lot like a canoe, and are designed so the sides come up around the children and provide them with a private space.
“The sides come up around them so they feel more secure and they have the pressure on them,” she said.
It gives the students the sensation that someone is hugging or holding them, Walker said.
“A lot of the time if they get upset, they want someone to hold them,” she said.
The pods offer an option for the students to have space to relax and calm themselves.
She hopes to have the pea pods in place by the time school starts. She expects to receive the grant funds by early August.
The first day of classes for Yukon is Aug. 15.
Walker said this is her first grant application.
She applied for the grant in March.
“I am super excited,” Walker said.
There were 70 applicants for the grant.
While Walker’s grant was the lone recipient in Yukon, grants also were awarded at Centennial Elementary in Mustang, at three schools in Deer Creek, and at Bethany High School.
“Together, we are helping students prepare for their future by funding critical classroom programs and curriculum. Through Cox Charities, our employees are thrilled to be able to support these innovative learning opportunities that engage and excite students,” said Kristin Peck, vice president of public affairs. “Our partnership with the schools across the state continues to grow, and we’re proud to be a strong part of that community.”
